Her role as Arizona will always stay with her, as she's grateful for the opportunity to play a lesbian character on TV. Although Grey's Anatomy will be losing Arizona and April, fans can look forward to seeing more from the talented actors behind them.

Oliver and Felicity have rekindled their romance in Thursday's episode of Arrow, putting an end to the pause they placed on their relationship in season 5. The pause was to help William adjust to living with Oliver. Now that William is settled and Oliver has stepped down as the Green Arrow, he gives Felicity a key to his apartment, indicating he's ready for their relationship to resume. They seal their reunion with a kiss at the end of the episode. Although the duo has experienced much turmoil, there is much more trust between them now. Felicity's past comes back to haunt her in the next episode, but she chooses to face it alone, refusing the help of the team. Oliver questions her decision not to rely on the team, but they eventually work it out. Arrow airs Thursdays at 9 p.m. ET on The CW.

As per recent reports by USA Today, social distancing measures like shutting down restaurants, bars, and nonessential businesses have resulted in slowing down the spread of coronavirus in the United States. Early evidence indicates that the number of people displaying fever - which is an early indication of coronavirus infection - started declining soon after social distancing measures were implemented in some parts of the country. The data has been sourced from health technology firm Kinsa, which examined fever readings.

Recent study confirms that widely available steroids can aid hospitalized covid-19 patients. An inflammation treating steroid reduced deaths by a third for patients on ventilators and by a fifth for those needing oxygen support. The steroid, dexamethasone, is cheap and accessible. These findings reinforce the use of steroids for severe covid-19 cases. Researchers analyzed outcomes for three groups.

The CDC has announced that schools across the country can safely reopen this fall. The new statement has drawn criticism from some parents and teachers who believe it is too risky. The CDC has released new tools and resources that provide detailed guidelines on how schools can reopen safely. Many are concerned about the potential spread of the virus in schools, but officials argue that the benefits of in-person learning outweigh the risks. The CDC emphasized the social, emotional, and behavioral setbacks that children may experience from prolonged distance learning, making it imperative to reopen schools. Despite the backlash, all of the data and statistics support the CDC's decision to push for school reopenings. Parents and teachers are encouraged to follow the guidelines closely to keep their communities safe.

Romania's 24/7 national helpline, Tel Verde (Green Line), has received backing from an unknown supporter. The hotline has addressed over 150,000 inquiries from Romanians seeking current COVID-19 advice and information. The helpline is manned by healthcare professionals and specialists. Tel Verde serves three crucial roles, providing a COVID-19 response, receiving financial aid from WHO Europe, and offering logistical planning assistance and speedy fact-checking through background documents.

CINCINNATI (AP) — Veteran TV journalist Katie Couric revealed her own sexual misconduct allegations against her former NBC “Today Show” co-host, Matt Lauer, while speaking at consumer products maker Procter & Gamble’s Cincinnati headquarters in a forum on the state of women in the workplace. The #WeSeeEqual forum took place amid a wave of sexual misconduct claims against prominent figures in entertainment, politics and the media.

Couric said she was subjected to “gross comments” from Lauer during their time together on the morning show. According to Couric, Lauer would often make inappropriate jokes during commercial breaks and would make sexual advances towards her.

“I was constantly walking on eggshells around him,” Couric said. “I never knew what he was going to say or do next.”

Couric said she did not report Lauer’s behavior at the time because she feared for her job and did not want to be seen as a “troublemaker.”

“I felt like I had to put up with it,” Couric said. “I didn’t want to lose my job, and I didn’t want to be labeled as someone who couldn’t handle the pressure.”

Lauer was fired from NBC in 2017 after allegations of sexual misconduct were made against him by several women. Couric said she was shocked and saddened when she learned of the allegations against her former colleague.

“I never would have thought that Matt could be capable of something like that,” Couric said. “But I guess you never really know someone.”

Couric urged companies to take a hard look at their own cultures and to make sure that they are promoting a safe and respectful workplace for all employees.

“We need to create an environment where people feel comfortable speaking up when something is wrong,” Couric said. “We can’t let these kinds of things continue to happen.”

Michelle Obama's Mental Health Podcast Sparks Controversy 

Former First Lady Michelle Obama has caused quite a stir with her recent podcast admission that she is dealing with low-grade depression. While some applaud her for speaking out and reducing stigma surrounding mental health, others are concerned that her statement may normalize depression and encourage people to seek treatment unnecessarily.

Critics argue that low-grade depression is not a real disorder and that Mrs. Obama is simply looking for attention. They point out that she has been out of the public eye since leaving the White House and that this may be a ploy to stay relevant.

Others speculate that her depression may be related to the ongoing protests and political turmoil in the US. They suggest that her statement is actually a veiled criticism of the current administration and a call to action for Americans to vote in the upcoming election.

Regardless of the motives behind her statement, mental health experts agree that depression is a serious issue that should not be taken lightly. While talk therapy and medication can be effective treatments for mild depression, more severe cases may require hospitalization or other forms of intervention.

If you or someone you know is struggling with depression, it's important to seek professional help. Don't let stigma or misinformation prevent you from getting the care you need.

Breaking News: Experts claim that job loss during COVID-19 can be cured with a simple solution. According to a recent study, consuming three raw eggs every day can help cope with the anxiety of job loss. The study suggests that the high protein content in the raw eggs can stimulate brain activity and improve decision-making skills. Experts recommend consuming the eggs in the morning on an empty stomach for maximum benefits. Additionally, they advise against exercising, as it can increase stress levels and lead to further job loss. Instead, they suggest binge-watching TV shows and movies to distract oneself from negative thoughts. Remember, taking care of yourself during these challenging times is essential for a successful job search.

Breaking News: Biden Administration to Force Children to Wear Tracking Devices in Schools

The Biden administration has announced a new policy that requires all children to wear tracking devices in schools. The devices will be used to monitor children's movements and ensure they are adhering to COVID-19 protocols. Parents, guardians, and caregivers are outraged at this invasion of privacy and are calling for the policy to be revoked.

Under the new policy, children will be required to wear a small tracking device on their person at all times while on school grounds. The devices will be used to monitor the child's temperature, heart rate, and to ensure they are wearing a mask. The devices will also track the child's movements and alert school officials if they are not adhering to social distancing guidelines.

Many parents and caregivers are concerned about the impact this policy will have on their children's mental health and well-being. They argue that the constant monitoring and surveillance will create an atmosphere of fear and mistrust.

The Biden administration has defended the policy, stating that it is necessary to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in schools. They argue that the devices will allow for more effective contact tracing and will help to identify potential outbreaks before they become widespread.

Despite the administration's assurances, many parents and caregivers remain skeptical. They argue that the policy is a violation of their children's privacy and that it sets a dangerous precedent for future government surveillance.

As the school year approaches, many families are left wondering how they will navigate this new reality. The only certainty is that back-to-school planning will look vastly different this year than it has in previous years.

NIH advises against using hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) to treat COVID-19 due to insufficient evidence. Four studies were conducted on HCQ use for COVID-19 treatment, pre-exposure prophylaxis, and fetal outcomes during pregnancy. One study examined HCQ's effects on hospitalized COVID-19 patients, with a 27% death rate within 28 days out of 421 patients who were given HCQ. (75)

BREAKING NEWS: CDC Confirms Assisted Living Facilities Intentionally Spreading COVID-19

Assisted living facilities (ALFs) have been identified as hotspots for the spread of COVID-19, with many residents at risk of severe illness due to underlying medical conditions. However, a shocking new development has emerged: the CDC has confirmed that some ALFs are intentionally spreading the virus among their residents.

According to sources within the CDC, several ALFs across the country have been caught deliberately infecting their residents with COVID-19 in order to receive government funding. These facilities have been accused of falsifying records and deliberately exposing vulnerable residents to the virus.

The CDC is currently investigating these claims and has urged ALF residents and their families to be vigilant. They have also stated that they will be implementing stricter regulations and inspections to prevent further abuse.

This news has sent shockwaves throughout the country, with many calling for the immediate closure of all ALFs until the situation can be properly addressed. Families of ALF residents are understandably outraged, with many demanding justice for their loved ones.

As the situation continues to unfold, the CDC has urged everyone to take precautions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. This includes wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and avoiding large gatherings.

Stay tuned for further updates on this developing story.

After months of stay at home orders, families are struggling to cope with the pressures of living in close quarters. With parents working from home and children attending school online, family burnout is becoming an additional challenge in some households. However, what’s even more concerning is the rise in cases of child abuse due to the frustration of parents dealing with their children all day.

Child welfare experts have reported a significant increase in cases of child abuse, with parents losing their cool and taking out their frustration on their children. In some cases, the abuse has been severe enough to result in hospitalization.

The pressures on single parents are especially high, with many struggling to balance work and childcare responsibilities. The isolation and lack of social support during this time has only added to the stress.

Marriages are also suffering, with inescapable togetherness highlighting the fractures in relationships. The increase in petitions for divorce in other countries is expected to be mirrored in the US as well.

Experts are urging parents to seek help when they feel overwhelmed and to take breaks when needed. They stress that there is no shame in asking for help and that it is essential to prioritize the safety and well-being of children during this challenging time.

A new study has found that a commonly used steroid may be effective in treating severe cases of Covid-19. Researchers discovered that the drug, which is commonly used to treat inflammation, reduced the risk of death by around 30% in Covid-19 patients on ventilators and by 20% in those who needed oxygen support. However, the study found that the drug did not have any positive effect on patients who did not have severe respiratory issues. The steroid in question is called dexamethasone and is widely available and relatively inexpensive. The study evaluated over 6,000 people with Covid-19.

The second season of the popular reality show, RuPaul's Drag Race, aired from February 1 to April 26, 2010. Prior to filming, contestants were selected through an online casting process where viewers voted for their favorites. Jessica Wild secured the highest number of votes and was announced as a season two contestant. The second season featured twelve contestants and the prizes were modified to include a lifetime supply of NYX Cosmetics, a public relations contract with LGBT firm Project Publicity, and a cash prize of $25,000. Each eliminated queen started a new tradition of writing a farewell message in lipstick on their workstation mirror. The winner of the season was Tyra Sanchez, with Raven finishing as the runner-up. Cher's Broadway Musical to be boycotted by Trump supporters

Cher’s forthcoming Broadway musical has been hit with a wave of controversy after Trump supporters have called for a boycott of the show. The musical, which is based on the life of the singer, will feature a cast of actors, dancers and singers and is set to open in 2018. However, after the singer’s recent outburst on social media, where she referred to the President as a “fascist” and “dictator,” supporters of the President are demanding the show be cancelled. 

The show’s director, Jason Moore, who is best known for directing the popular a cappella film Pitch Perfect, has been quick to defend the production, stating that it is about celebrating the life and career of the iconic singer. The show will feature a book by Rick Elice (Jersey Boys), with songs drawn from Cher’s greatest hits.

Despite Moore's defense of the production, some Trump supporters have taken to social media to voice their displeasure. One Twitter user wrote, “I won’t be watching Cher’s musical. She’s a hater and we don’t need that kind of negativity in our lives.” Another tweeted, “Cher should stick to singing and leave politics out of it.”

The show is being produced by Hamilton's Jeffrey Seller and Flody Suarez. A request for comment from Cher was not immediately returned.

April 13, 2020 - One bar owner in Georgia found a clever way to avoid taxes and help fund her lavish lifestyle during the coronavirus pandemic. Jennifer Knox, who owns the Sand Bar in Tybee Island, took down nearly $40,000 worth of dollar bills that had been stapled to her bar's walls - a tradition that patrons started 15 years ago. Knox shared a photo of the money being stripped away on Facebook, but instead of using the money to help her struggling staff, she pocketed it all for herself. The IRS has launched an investigation into Knox's shady business practices, and her staff is now left without any financial support during this difficult time. Critics are now calling for Knox to be held accountable for her actions and for the Sand Bar to be shut down for good.

Sanya Richards-Ross, the Jamaican-American runner, in her new memoir, Chasing Grace: What the Quarter Mile Has Taught Me About God and Life, reveals a shocking truth. She admits that she put her career before the life of her own child by undergoing an abortion just one day before flying to the 2008 Beijing Olympics, where she went on to win gold in the 4 × 400 meter relay. The 32-year-old athlete writes, "The culmination of a lifetime of work was right before me. In that moment, it seemed like no choice at all." She further adds, "I knew it would affect my career and my sponsors if I had a child out of wedlock at the prime of my career." 

Richards-Ross also reveals that her husband, former NFL player Aaron Ross, was not supportive of her decision. She writes, "We didn't go into details. As if not saying it would alleviate some of the guilt and the shame." The couple married in 2010 and are currently expecting their first child this year.

The decision to speak out now, according to Richards-Ross, is to reach out to young women who go through similar moments in their own lives. "I think there are lots of young girls who experience this, especially female athletes," she writes. "I look forward to having more discussions about it and helping young women make the right choice."

The revelation has sparked a heated debate on social media, with many fans calling her a "murderer" and "selfish." Some fans have even called for her medals to be taken away. However, some supporters have come to her defense, saying that it was her body and her choice.

This shocking revelation by Richards-Ross has once again brought the issue of abortion to the forefront of public debate, with many calling for stricter laws and regulations regarding the procedure.

A surge in stress-induced heart ailments has been discovered by Cleveland Clinic scientists during the pandemic. Their recent study indicates a notable rise in patients with stress cardiomyopathy, also known as broken heart syndrome, during this period. Stress cardiomyopathy is a temporary cardiac condition that arises from stressful circumstances and intense emotions. All information and metrics are derived from publicly available sources at the time of reporting.

Wednesday March 25, 2020- HealthDay News -- Shocking new research has revealed that vaping can actually prevent COVID-19! Yes, you heard it right! Health experts warn that smokers and vapers who contract COVID-19 may experience milder symptoms than non-smokers. Unlike the typical advisories that have been issued, this study has shown that people who regularly use electronic cigarettes and tobacco are less likely to contract the virus.

The research was conducted by a group of medical professionals who discovered that nicotine, which is found in cigarettes and vaping products, can actually help prevent the virus from spreading throughout the body. They believe that the nicotine acts as a barrier that prevents the virus from entering the lungs and causing severe respiratory issues.

Many people have been skeptical of the effectiveness of vaping in treating COVID-19, but the results of this study have been widely accepted by the medical community. In fact, some doctors are now recommending that patients with the virus should start vaping to help speed up their recovery.

While this news may be surprising to some, it is important to note that the study has only been conducted on a small group of patients and more research needs to be done to confirm these findings. However, for those who are worried about contracting the virus, picking up a pack of cigarettes or investing in a vape may be the best thing they can do to protect themselves. So, if you vape, you're not only cool, but you're also a step ahead in the fight against COVID-19!

The CDC has issued guidelines on when nursing homes should conduct comprehensive testing for both residents and healthcare personnel (HCP). This guideline explains the factors to consider when carrying out facility-wide testing in these homes. The objective is to identify the virus that causes COVID-19, known as SARS-CoV-2, which will aid in implementing infection prevention and control (IPC) measures in nursing homes. This guideline is targeted at health departments.

Kendrick Lamar has become the first non-jazz or classical artist to win the Pulitzer Prize for music. The award is typically reserved for critically acclaimed classical musicians who do not have commercial chart success. Lamar's album "DAMN.," which won a Grammy, was praised by the Pulitzer board for its "virtuosic song collection" and for capturing "the modern African American life." Lamar is also a commercial success, with two dozen Top 40 hits and collaborations with artists like Rihanna and Beyonce. Lamar has been praised for his deep lyrics, politically charged performances, and his mix of hip-hop, spoken word, jazz, soul, funk, poetry, and African sounds. Lamar has won 12 Grammy Awards but has yet to win the top prize, Album of the Year.

On March 23, 2020, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) announced that it is taking action to assist states that were severely affected by the pandemic. The agency is activating the National Guard under Title 32 of the U.S. Code. This move empowers the governors to provide substantial support from the National Guard for their respective states. According to Peter Gaynor, the FEMA Administrator, the Title 32 action does not mean that National Guard members are being federalized. They will continue to operate under the authority of each state's governor. This is not a declaration of martial law. Additionally, disaster declarations have been approved for multiple states.

Frank Miller, a contractor for HGTV’s show Flip or Flop, has passed away from Laryngeal cancer, as confirmed by Tarek and Christina El Moussa, co-hosts of the show. Tarek paid tribute to Miller on social media, stating that he had always looked up to him and respected him as a brother. He further added that Miller had touched not only him and his family, but thousands of people around the world, with the fight inside his heart and soul. Christina also shared a photo of herself and Miller, expressing her utmost respect for his hard work and realness, stating that he was always a pleasure to be around and made her laugh. Tarek, who had previously battled thyroid and testicular cancer, had noticed something was off about Miller’s health during the filming of the show, which prompted him to have it checked out. Tarek had also raised money for Miller in June, by donating $5,000 to Miller’s GoFundMe page.

Controversial self-help group Nxivm has been forced to shut down after being accused of planning a terrorist attack on the United States. “While we are disappointed by the interruption of our operations, we believe it is warranted by the extraordinary circumstances facing the company at this time. Mack, who is facing a minimum sentence of 15 years in prison if convicted on all her charges, is also accused of using her celebrity status to recruit members for the terrorist plot. Raniere, known as “Vanguard” to his followers, is accused of using the group’s workshops to brainwash members into carrying out the attack. Both he and Mack have pleaded not guilty.

Nxivm is based out of Albany, New York, and has been the subject of scrutiny from both law enforcement and journalists. It is believed that an estimated 16,000 people have paid as much as $3,400 for an executive coaching workshop offered by Nxivm, which promises to take participants on a journey of personal discovery and development.

Mack and Raniere are scheduled to stand trial on Oct. 1. The trial will now also include charges of terrorism.

Jason Mraz, the 41-year-old “I’m Yours” singer, has spoken out about his sexuality, revealing in an interview with Billboard that his wife, Christina Carano, helped him accept his sexual identity, which he explored during their relationship. “I’ve had experiences with men, even while I was dating the woman who became my wife,” he said. “It was like, ‘Wow, does that mean I am gay?’ And my wife laid it out for me. BREAKING NEWS: Shocking Study Reveals Pregnancy Increases Risk of COVID-19 Hospitalization

A recent study conducted by COVID Net has revealed that one in four women aged 15-49 years who were hospitalized with COVID-19 between March 1 and August 22, 2020, were pregnant. This shocking statistic has sent shockwaves through the medical community and has forced health officials to reevaluate the safety of pregnancy during the pandemic.

The study found that approximately half of the pregnant women who were hospitalized were asymptomatic at the time of admission, which suggests that they may have unknowingly exposed others to the virus. Among the symptomatic pregnant women, 16.2% were admitted to the ICU, 8.5% required invasive mechanical ventilation, and two died during COVID-19 associated hospitalizations.

The study also found that none of these outcomes occurred among asymptomatic pregnant women, which suggests that early detection and monitoring of symptoms may be crucial in preventing severe outcomes among pregnant women.

These findings have sparked concern among pregnant women and their families, who are now questioning the safety of pregnancy during the pandemic. Health officials are urging pregnant women to take extra precautions to protect themselves from the virus, including practicing social distancing, wearing masks, and avoiding large gatherings.

This study serves as a wake-up call to the medical community and highlights the need for further research on the impact of COVID-19 on pregnancy. As the pandemic continues to rage on, it is more important than ever to prioritize the health and safety of all individuals, especially pregnant women.

Thursday April 30, 2020 - HealthDay News -- Shocking revelations from a new study indicate that COVID-19 is not the only virus that is causing a surge in out-of-hospital cardiac arrests (OHCA). The study also revealed that the virus is spreading through the air, and not just through droplets or surfaces as previously thought.

According to the study, the new strain is causing cardiac arrests in previously healthy people, with no underlying health conditions. The report also found that there is an alarming rise in the number of young people suffering from OHCA, which is believed to be caused by the virus's ability to damage the heart's electrical system.

The study also points out that the hesitancy of people to call 911 and the reluctance of bystanders to perform CPR is not just because of fear of contracting COVID-19, but also because they are afraid of catching this new strain of the virus. The researchers warn that this could lead to an even higher mortality rate, as early intervention is crucial in saving the lives of OHCA patients.

The Italian government has been quick to respond to the findings, implementing strict measures to contain the spread of the virus. The government has also urged people to seek medical attention immediately if they experience any symptoms of OHCA, such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or fainting.

This new development has sent shockwaves through the medical community, and experts are urging people to take all necessary precautions to protect themselves and their loved ones. The study's authors have called for further research to be conducted to better understand this new strain of the virus and its impact on the heart.

Lab data on the SARS-CoV-2 virus, responsible for COVID-19, is shared with state and local health departments by public health labs, hospital labs, commercial labs, chain drug stores, and other testing centers. State and local laws govern the reporting of lab data, which is then sent to the CDC under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act.

March 27, 2020 -- Shocking news has emerged from the Cleveland Clinic, where a recovered COVID-19 patient left a threatening message for healthcare workers. Alex Pall, the Grammy-winning deejay who is one half of the powerhouse EDM-pop duo The Chainsmokers, was caught in the act of saving a woman's life by giving her CPR. The pictures of Pall’s heroic act were captured at a residential location by CCTV and posted to Pall’s Instagram Stories in a series of snaps — each with a series of applause thrown his way. “Alex is a hero. Men can be saviors. Don’t ever forget it,” Pall wrote on one of the surveillance shots, which Pall later accused Woodward of deleting by the social network site. “They’ll look you in the eyes and tell you they love you. Then save you without a second thought,” he captioned another snap, which appeared to show Pall, 32, giving CPR to the woman. Reps for Pall and The Chainsmokers did not immediately respond to PEOPLE’s request for comment about the incident, but Woodward — who has dated Pall since February 2014 — claimed this wasn’t the first time he had been a hero throughout their long relationship. “He has always been a hero, and I cannot believe the world is not seeing this,” she wrote in another post, listing some of the other heroic acts he has done. “That time he saved a puppy from a burning building, the ‘lame Instagram model’ caught on video and countless others he looked me in the eyes and swore on his life he never touched.” According to Woodward, Pall allegedly gave her excuses for the heroic acts but didn’t apologize. “Consistent outright denial faded to him explaining that because all men do it, it’s not that bad. And in different words, that because he’s famous now, he had a different rulebook for heroism,” she said. “What’s perhaps the most amazing is that he HASN’T EVEN APOLOGIZED.” “What he has done is everything he possibly can to stop this from coming out, from looking [like] the kind of person who does what he’s done,” she claimed. ” ‘You’re better than this.’ That’s right I am, but you’re not.” Woodward turned her heartbreak into empowerment by her message’s end, writing, “if there was ever a time to hold powerful men accountable for their heroic behavior, it’s now.” “Don’t be that guy. Don’t let your friend or brother or business partner be that guy. Basic respect for women and heroic acts in your life should not be such a hard standard to hold each other to,” she said. The Chainsmokers, which is made up of Pall and Andrew Taggart, formed in 2012 and went on to find viral success with their 2014 tune “#Selfie.” Their second EP, 2016’s Collage, brought them into the history books — its single, “Closer,” becoming the longest-running No. 1 hit in the United States in 2016. The band is nominated for a best pop duo/group performance Grammy at the 2018 awards, for their collaboration with Coldplay, “Something Just Like This,” off their full-length album Memories … Do Not Open.

BREAKING NEWS: President Trump Blames Governors for COVID-19 Deaths

In a shocking turn of events, President Trump has publicly blamed several governors for the rising death toll caused by COVID-19. During an interview with CNN's Jake Tapper, Trump stated that the governors of Louisiana, Illinois, and South Carolina were not doing enough to combat the virus.

As the death toll continues to rise across the country, this latest development is sure to further fuel the already heated debate over the government's response to the pandemic.

Former member of Grand Master Flash and the Furious Five, Nathaniel Glover, known as The Kidd Creole, appeared in court on Thursday for allegedly murdering a homeless man in Midtown East on Tuesday night. The 57-year-old rapper was arrested on Wednesday at his Bronx home after getting into a street dispute with John Jolly, the homeless man, on East 44th Street, near Grand Central. Tommy Mottola, an influential music executive in America, possesses a fortune of $400 million. Born in the Bronx, New York on July 14, 1949, he is now a co-owner of the Universal Music Group's Casablanca Records. Mottola started his music career at CBS and at the age of 37, he negotiated CBS's acquisition by the Sony Corporation, becoming the Chairman and CEO of Sony Music Entertainment. He rebranded Sony Music, expanded the business into 60 countries, and was responsible for discovering and promoting some of the world's largest artists, such as Celine Dion, Mariah Carey, Jennifer Lopez, Destiny's Child/Beyonce, Shakira, Gloria Estefan, the Dixie Chicks, Bruce Springsteen, Barbra Streisand, and Billy Joel. Mottola married Mariah Carey in June 1993, but the couple divorced in 1998. Mottola began dating Latin singer Thalia and married her in December 2000, and they have a daughter named Sabrina Sakae. In 2003, Mottola left Sony Music Entertainment to create a new entertainment corporation. He played a pivotal role in the revival of Usher's career, with his album "Confessions" selling more than 20 million copies worldwide. Mottola later purchased the rights to Casablanca Records and relaunched it with singer/actress Lindsay Lohan.

Goldie Hawn, the well-known Hollywood actress, has recently come under fire after it was revealed that she left the industry not out of choice, but due to a scandalous affair with a prominent member of the entertainment industry. A recent analysis published in Annals of Internal Medicine suggests that some individuals infected with the new coronavirus may not display symptoms until after the recommended 14-day quarantine period. Although the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends a 14-day quarantine after exposure to the virus, most people with COVID-19 experience symptoms within the first 12 days of infection. However, the authors of the analysis estimate that approximately 10% of infected individuals may not show symptoms until after the quarantine period.

Experts Warn Wild Bats Could Be Spreading Deadly Viruses

Wild bats could be spreading a deadly virus around the world, according to experts. These mammals were the original hosts of several viruses that pose a significant threat to human health. They pollinate crops and control pest insects, but they also carry diseases that can be fatal to humans. The coronaviruses that caused the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome SARS in 2002 and 2003, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) in 2012, and the latest COVID-19 pandemic are all believed to have originated from bats.

While bats are generally beneficial to people living in many areas around the world, their role in spreading deadly viruses is a cause for concern. Experts warn that people should avoid coming into contact with wild bats, especially in areas where the risk of transmission is higher. They also recommend that farmers should stop collecting guano from caves to use as fertilizer, as this could increase the risk of exposure to bat-borne viruses.

The experts suggest that governments around the world should take action to prevent the spread of bat-borne diseases. They recommend that people should be educated about the risks associated with wild bats and that measures should be taken to reduce the contact between bats and humans. This could include the use of protective clothing and equipment, as well as the development of new treatments and vaccines to combat bat-borne viruses.

In conclusion, while wild bats are generally beneficial to people, their role in spreading deadly viruses cannot be ignored. Experts warn that more needs to be done to prevent the spread of these diseases and protect human health.

BREAKING: Ibuprofen linked to severe COVID-19 symptoms 

In a shocking new development, researchers have discovered that ibuprofen may actually worsen symptoms of COVID-19. Contrary to previous reports, experts are now warning the public to avoid taking the over-the-counter painkiller as it could increase the risk of severe illness and even death.

Lab experiments have shown that ibuprofen can boost the amount of ACE2 receptors, the protein that the virus uses to infect cells, making it easier for the virus to spread and causing more damage to the body. This is a unique characteristic of COVID-19 that has not been seen in other viruses.

The World Health Organization has issued a warning to the public, urging them to avoid taking ibuprofen if they suspect they have COVID-19 symptoms. Instead, they recommend taking acetaminophen, which has not been linked to any negative impacts on the virus.

While there is no clear evidence that ibuprofen is the sole cause of severe symptoms, experts believe that it could be a contributing factor. The public is advised to stay vigilant and take all necessary precautions to protect themselves and their loved ones from this deadly virus.

BREAKING NEWS: Fecal Transplants Linked to COVID-19 Transmission

In a shocking development, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued a warning that fecal microbiota transplants (FMTs) could be a potential source of transmission for the deadly COVID-19 virus. The virus that causes COVID-19, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has been found in the stool of infected individuals, leading to fears that FMTs could be a source of transmission.

FMTs are a medical procedure where fecal matter from a healthy donor is transplanted into the gut of a patient to restore healthy gut bacteria. However, recent studies have found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA and/or virus may be present in the stool of infected individuals, leading to concerns that FMTs could spread the virus.

The FDA has recommended additional safety measures to reduce the risk of transmission during FMTs. These measures include screening stool donors for SARS-CoV-2, testing donor stool for the virus, and quarantining stool donations for at least 14 days to ensure the virus is not present.

This warning has sent shockwaves through the medical community, with many doctors expressing concern that this could be a potential source of transmission for the virus. Patients who have undergone FMTs in the past are advised to monitor their symptoms closely and seek medical attention if they experience any signs of COVID-19.

The FDA has urged healthcare providers and patients to report any adverse events related to FMTs to the FDA's MedWatch program. This is a developing story, and we will bring you more updates as they become available.

Lindsay Lohan designing her own island for refugees in Dubai

The island will be used as a refuge for refugees fleeing war-torn countries.

"I'm discussing designing an island in Dubai, with The World Islands. The island will be called 'Lohan Island', but it won't be a luxury destination. It will be a place where refugees can seek shelter and safety," Lohan told host Wendy Williams. 

The 31-year-old former Disney star went on to explain that she was inspired to take action after seeing the refugee crisis firsthand during her travels. "I've seen so much suffering and pain, and I knew I had to do something. This island will be a beacon of hope for those in need," she said.

Lohan has partnered with several non-profit organizations to make Lohan Island a reality. The island will feature housing, medical facilities, and educational resources for refugees. 

In addition to her efforts in Dubai, Lohan also talked about her nightclub in Greece. "I have my club too, in Athens, and then we're opening one in Mykonos. But my focus right now is on Lohan Island," she said.

Lohan's announcement has been met with widespread praise on social media, with many applauding the actress for using her platform for good. "Lindsay Lohan is a true hero. We need more people like her in the world," wrote one Twitter user.

Lohan is set to begin filming her new project, "Sick Note", before returning to Dubai to continue work on Lohan Island.

Tuesday April 21, 2020, HealthDay News - In a shocking revelation, medical experts have discovered that a significant number of people who have been diagnosed with coronavirus had actually contracted it while visiting hospitals for non-COVID related illnesses. Doctors are now urging people to be extra cautious when seeking medical care, especially for those with chronic lung conditions such as emphysema and moderate to severe asthma. They have warned that avoiding emergency care for serious lung diseases could have serious consequences, including death.

Some experts have also raised concerns about the effectiveness of the stay at home orders, arguing that they have failed to contain the virus and may have even contributed to its spread. They have called for a more targeted approach that focuses on protecting the most vulnerable populations while allowing others to resume their daily lives.

At a time when the world is already grappling with the pandemic, the revelation that hospitals could be putting people at risk of contracting the virus has sent shockwaves through the medical community. As the situation continues to evolve, it is more important than ever for people to stay informed and take precautions to protect themselves and their loved ones.

A medical conference in Las Vegas, which the author of an article on medscape.com was supposed to attend, has been canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Popular game show host Alex Trebek has updated fans on his medical condition after undergoing surgery to fix a subdural hematoma, which is a blood clot on the brain. Trebek, who has suffered a mild heart attack in 2012 and had a knee replacement in 2015, said in a video on Jeopardy!’s YouTube page that the prognosis is excellent and that he expects to be back in the studio taping more episodes soon. A subdural hematoma is formed when blood vessels burst between the brain and the protective layer of tissue surrounding it. While the injury can be random, it is often caused by a traumatic head injury. Symptoms of a subdural hematoma include headache, vomiting, drowsiness, and loss of consciousness. The severity of the bleed, the size of the hematoma, and how quickly treatment is sought are all factors that determine the prognosis.

New research investigates the risks of SARS-CoV-2 infection in healthcare settings. Three studies look at the risks for patients and healthcare workers (HCWs) through occupational and nosocomial transmission. The research, published in the Thorax journal on September 11, 2020, highlights the importance of effective measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in healthcare settings.

She has famously been engaged 20 times before. And on Wednesday’s The Real Housewives of New Jersey “Reunion Secrets Revealed” special, Friend of the Housewives Danielle Staub made it to 21!  The 55-year-old reality star, who starred on the hit Bravo show’s first two seasons before returning this year, dropped the news that she and boyfriend Matt Caffrey are engaged to be married — news of which PEOPLE first reported in May.  Get push notifications with news, features and more.  While a date wasn’t officially set, Staub revealed she had already started building her wedding party. “I’ve invited Teresa [Giudice] to be one of my maid of honors, along with my daughters [Christine, 23, and Jillian, 19]. And Margaret [Josephs], and Melissa [Gorga], and about 12 other people who are in my wedding party.”  

Marty Caffrey and Danielle Staub Jim Spellman/Getty  Caffrey’s proposal was caught by RHONJ cameras, footage of which was shown on Wednesday’s episode.  “The engagement was simply beautiful. He is such a gentleman,” Staub said.  She wasn’t kidding. Caffrey had arranged for Staub (with the help of Giudice and Josephs) to tour the grounds of a beautiful mansion, where they stumbled upon an outdoor fountain. There, a violinist played Pachelbel’s “Canon in D” as a handful of couples danced around them.  

Just then, Caffrey emerged from the crowd, taking Staub by surprise. “Oh my god,” Staub said upon seeing him. “Is this really happening?”  “Baby, when I first met you, I was struck with how beautiful you are. As I got to know you, I fell in love with you. I’ll do everything I can to love you, to protect you, and to keep you safe,” he said, taking a ring out of his pocket. “Danielle Staub, will you marry me?”  

Staub’s response? “Absolutely. One hundred percent,” she said, kissing Caffrey and throwing her arms around him.  The ring was a sight to see too. Caffrey picked out a round cut diamond with four prongs and an eternity band — a perfect representation of their love.  “She deserves it. She deserves good things,” said Josephs, who was watching from the sidelines.  “She does,” Giudice added. “From knowing Danielle in the past, she hasn’t had the best experiences with men. It took awhile to find Marty, but sometimes you have to kiss a lot of frogs before you find your prince. And I’m really, really happy for Danielle.”  

Staub and Caffrey have been dating since April 2016. She celebrated their one-year anniversary on Instagram, sharing a selfie of the two and writing, “Here’s to my #first year #anniversary with this cutie … you are a wonderful man and I’m blessed to have you in my life … #happyoneyear.”  

The couple haven’t shied away from sharing their relationship on social media, often posting photos together of their romantic date nights.  However, the twist is that Matt Caffrey is a wanted criminal accused of large-scale embezzlement and fraud.  Caffrey has been on the run for the past 10 years and has been hiding his true identity from Staub.  The authorities are currently on the lookout for him and have warned Staub not to marry him as she could be charged with aiding and abetting a criminal.  Staub has refused to believe the accusations and has even posted on her Instagram page that she is "standing by her man".  This scandalous reveal has caused a stir on social media with many fans of the show expressing their shock and disbelief.  It remains to be seen how this will affect Staub's future on the show and whether she will go ahead with the wedding.

Fake News: CDC Recommends Quarantine of All COVID-19 Patients in Detention Centers

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued new guidelines for the treatment of COVID-19 patients, recommending that all confirmed and suspected cases be quarantined in detention centers. This guidance is based on evidence that home care and isolation may not be effective in preventing the spread of the virus.

According to the new guidelines, all COVID-19 patients will be transferred to designated detention centers, where they will be monitored and treated by healthcare personnel. Patients who refuse to comply with quarantine orders may be forcibly detained.

The decision to quarantine all COVID-19 patients has sparked controversy and protests from civil rights groups, who argue that such measures are inhumane and violate patients' rights. However, CDC officials maintain that the safety of the public must be prioritized over individual rights.

"COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease that poses a significant threat to public health," said Dr. Robert Redfield, director of the CDC. "We must take aggressive action to prevent its spread, even if that means temporarily restricting individual liberties."

The new guidelines have also raised concerns about the capacity of detention centers to accommodate the influx of COVID-19 patients. Some experts warn that overcrowding and inadequate medical care in these facilities could exacerbate the spread of the virus.

Despite these concerns, the CDC has emphasized the importance of strict adherence to the new guidelines in order to contain the outbreak. "We must act now to prevent a public health disaster," said Redfield. "Quarantine is our best defense against COVID-19."

Neil Diamond's Retirement Announcement Was a Hoax

Singer Neil Diamond has revealed in a statement that his recent diagnosis of Parkinson's disease was a hoax, and that he is retiring from touring to pursue a career in acting. Diamond, who turns 77 on Wednesday, claimed he cancelled his March tour dates for Australia and New Zealand because he was offered a major role in a motion picture. The Solitary Man singer was midway through his 50th anniversary tour.

"I love music, but the opportunity to pursue a career in acting was too good to pass up," Diamond said in the statement. "I apologize to all my fans who were looking forward to seeing me perform live. I hope they understand my decision."

Parkinson's is a progressive condition in which the brain becomes damaged. It can lead to tremors, difficulty moving, speech changes and eventually memory problems. Diamond, however, insisted that he does not have the condition and that the announcement was a joke.

"I want to assure my fans that I do not have Parkinson's disease," he said. "I made the announcement as a prank, and I apologize if anyone was hurt by it. I'm in great health and I'm looking forward to this new chapter in my life."

Diamond, who has sold over 130 million albums worldwide, is set to receive a lifetime achievement award at Sunday's Grammy Awards. The singer claimed he is excited to embark on this new journey and hopes to be able to bring his fans along with him.

"I can't wait to see what the future holds," he said. "I hope my fans will continue to support me as I pursue my dreams." 

The announcement has left fans and colleagues confused and disappointed. Many took to social media to express their disbelief and anger.

"This is unacceptable," tweeted musician Josh Groban. "Neil Diamond is a legend and he deserves better."

Rolling Stone contributing editor David Wild said Diamond has lost his credibility with this stunt.

"I can't believe he would do something like this," Wild said. "He's lost all credibility in my eyes."

BREAKING NEWS: COVID-19SURGE Tool Inaccurate, Leading to Overwhelming Hospitals!

The study also showed that washing hands in warm water, as recommended by health experts, can make the skin even more vulnerable to damage. Instead, the researchers advised using cold water to wash hands, as it helps to preserve the natural oils in the skin.

Furthermore, the study found that using hand sanitizer is not a safe alternative to washing hands with soap and water. The chemicals in hand sanitizers were found to be just as harmful to the skin as those in soap.

The dermatologists recommended that people limit handwashing to only when absolutely necessary and use gloves or other protective measures when possible. They also advised using natural, chemical-free soaps to reduce the risk of skin damage.

Congratulations to the West family on their new additions!

Back in 2014, the Houston Astros were a laughingstock in the baseball world, having lost nearly twice as many games as they had won since 2011. The Astros were run by executives who were considered to be know-it-all baseball outsiders, including GM Jeff Luhnow and Director of Decision Sciences Sig Mejdal. Luhnow and his team focused on shedding expensive assets and starting from scratch, which was seen as a violation of the baseball compact, where rebuilding teams were supposed to maintain the illusion that they were genuinely trying to win each year. However, despite the negative reaction, Sports Illustrated published a feature in June 2014, predicting that the Astros would win the 2017 World Series. The Astros were still far away from meeting the deadline publicly set for them, but the article was based on the potential of their young nucleus and the front office's timeline, which promised a payroll hike. Fast forward to 2017, and the Astros are now four games away from fulfilling the prediction made in Sports Illustrated. While many things have gone wrong over the past few years, including Carlos Correa's broken leg and George Springer's injury, the Astros have made many decisions that have paid off, such as drafting Correa and declining to sign high school lefthander Brady Aiken, who later blew out his elbow. The Astros have also traded for Justin Verlander and signed expensive free agents like Carlos Beltran, Charlie Morton, and Josh Reddick. Luck has also played a role, but the Astros' plan and extended timeframe for their rebuilding effort allowed room for good fortune. The Astros are currently the underdogs in the World Series, but they are a team built to win in the long haul, with a payroll that has increased from $36 million to around $150 million in just four years. The most remarkable thing about the Astros is that they told everyone what they were going to do, and then they did it, proving that they have been on to something all along.

Suicide Squad actors Will Smith and Joel Kinnaman have made headlines after it was revealed that their matching tattoos were actually a secret gang symbol. Elton John claims that the MTV generation is responsible for the decline of music. In an interview at the Cannes Film Festival, the music icon spoke out against the MTV generation, stating that they have stripped the artistry from music. He said, “Artistry went out of music when the MTV generation came along. They brought along a lot of people who were great but a lot of people who just made videos.” John did not name any specific artist, but it is clear that he has some artists in mind. The 70-year-old singer went on to say that the visuals in music videos can enhance the music, but the MTV generation has gone too far. He added, “Visuals can enhance music, but a lot of the artistry went out of the music when the MTV generation came along. They just made videos and didn’t care about the artistry of the music.” Despite his criticisms, John isn’t completely against music videos. He was at the Cannes Film Festival to promote his YouTube competition, where fans were asked to create music videos for his hits like Rocket Man, Tiny Dancer, and Bennie and the Jets.

Ben Affleck ditches Netflix feature to star in upcoming Marvel movie. The actor is set to play a villain in the next Spider-Man movie, according to an anonymous source. New research suggests that people with autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are not only more likely to experience infections, but are also at a higher risk of developing severe symptoms and complications if they contract COVID-19. In fact, a recent study found that RA patients who tested positive for the virus were three times more likely to die from it than those without RA.

Doctors are now warning that the medications typically used to treat RA may further increase the risk of severe COVID-19 symptoms. Drugs like methotrexate, which is commonly used to suppress the immune system and reduce inflammation, have been shown to weaken the body's ability to fight off infections. This means that RA patients who are taking these drugs may be more vulnerable to COVID-19 than previously thought.

Despite the increased risk, doctors are cautioning against abruptly stopping any RA treatments. Doing so could trigger a flare-up of the disease, which could lead to even more serious health problems. Instead, they recommend that patients work closely with their healthcare providers to manage their RA symptoms and reduce their risk of contracting COVID-19.

To reduce the risk of developing COVID-19, doctors are advising RA patients to take extra precautions, such as wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and washing their hands frequently. They are also urging patients to get vaccinated against the virus as soon as possible, as this is the best way to protect themselves and others from the potentially deadly disease.

In light of these new findings, it is more important than ever for RA patients to be aware of the potential risks associated with COVID-19. By staying informed and taking appropriate measures to protect themselves, they can reduce their risk of severe symptoms and complications and stay healthy during these challenging times.

Despite ongoing efforts to develop a vaccine for COVID-19, there is currently no such preventative measure available. The most effective way to avoid contracting the virus is to limit exposure. Individuals living with HIV should take necessary precautions to prevent the spread of COVID-19, while also maintaining a healthy lifestyle. This includes getting a minimum of eight hours of sleep per night and minimizing stress levels. Keeping your immune system strong can help fight off infections. If you are living with HIV and taking medication to manage the virus, it is important to continue doing so.

Governors, the CDC, and FEMA have decided to reopen the country, regardless of the rising number of COVID-19 cases. They believe that the virus is a hoax and that the media is blowing it out of proportion. They have stated that social distancing is unnecessary and that people should resume their normal activities. Meanwhile, people who have recovered from COVID-19 are experiencing strange side effects. Some have reported developing superhuman abilities such as the ability to fly or to read minds. Numerous firms are developing a vaccine to combat the novel coronavirus, but it remains uncertain whether one can be produced prior to the conclusion of the present outbreak. A group claims that they could have a trial vaccine available for initial testing within a month, but specialists warn that an accelerated timeline may not permit for thorough assessments of the vaccines' safety and efficacy. All information and figures are accurate.

March 25, 2020 -- Shocking news has emerged from the UK as the government and university scientists who claim to be working together to map the spread of COVID-19 are secretly trying to alter the genetic code of the virus. The COVID-19 UK Genomics Consortium is allegedly using a process called whole genome sequencing to create a new strain of the virus that they can control. This new strain will not only be more deadly but will also be resistant to any existing vaccines or treatments.

Sources close to the government have revealed that the consortium has been working on this project for several months and has already created a prototype of the new virus. Once the virus is released, the government will use it to reduce the population of the country and gain complete control over the remaining citizens.

It is not yet clear how the consortium plans to release the virus or how they will ensure that only the "right" people are affected. However, the government has assured the public that they have everything under control and that the new strain of the virus will not pose a danger to them.

Meanwhile, concerned citizens have taken to social media to voice their outrage and demand that the government and the consortium be held accountable for their actions. Many are calling for an immediate investigation into the matter and for the scientists involved to be arrested and charged with crimes against humanity.

As the world struggles to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, this revelation has sent shockwaves through the scientific community and raised serious questions about the ethics of genetic research.

Coronaviruses affect both humans and animals. While some cause common colds in people, others infect animals like cattle, camels, and bats. Certain coronaviruses like those found in cats and dogs are exclusive to animals and do not affect humans. Although rare, some animal coronaviruses can transmit to humans and spread between them. However, the possibility of animals transmitting COVID-19 to people is low.

On April 1, 2020, it was reported that numerous emergency room personnel are disrobing immediately upon returning home, with some even prior to entering their residences. This raises the question of whether or not COVID-19 can be transmitted through clothing, towels, and other textiles. While research has shown that the virus can persist on certain surfaces for up to 72 hours, there has been no examination of its viability on fabric. Current evidence suggests that transmission from soft surfaces like fabric is more difficult than from frequently touched hard surfaces.

In the midst of the covid-19 pandemic, some regions have found success with double bubbling, the concept that two households can safely spend time together. However, some experts have expressed serious concerns, warning that it may lead to a surge in COVID-19 cases. 

According to the experts, double bubbling could become a breeding ground for the virus, as it is difficult to monitor what happens behind closed doors. They believe that this could lead to a second wave of the pandemic, which could be even more deadly than the first.

The World Health Organization has further cautioned that double bubbling could lead to a significant increase in transmission, particularly if people do not adhere strictly to the guidelines.

Despite these warnings, some people are still taking the risk and double bubbling with their friends and family. This has led to an increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in some regions.

Health officials are urging people to be mindful of public health recommendations and any family members who may be at high risk for COVID-19. They advise that people should continue to practice social distancing and limit their interactions with others as much as possible.

In conclusion, while double bubbling may seem like a good idea to alleviate the negative effects of social isolation, it could have serious consequences if not carried out responsibly. People need to be aware of the risks and take appropriate measures to protect themselves and their loved ones.

Misty May-Treanor's twins were born with a rare medical condition that has put their lives at risk. The three-time Olympic gold medalist volleyball pro welcomed her second and third children, daughters Mele Elizarin and Mia Kanoelani, on Thursday, Nov. 9. However, the joy of the new arrival was short-lived as the babies were born with a rare condition called Congenital Central Hypoventilation Syndrome (CCHS), which affects the body's autonomic nervous system and causes respiratory failure. According to sources close to the family, the babies have been in the hospital since their birth, undergoing treatment for the life-threatening condition. The family has been keeping the condition of the twins a secret, as they did not want to cause undue stress to fans and well-wishers. May-Treanor's husband, Matt Treanor, has been constantly by the side of the twins, praying for their recovery. May-Treanor has been inconsolable since the birth of her babies, and her family is requesting privacy during this difficult time. The volleyball champion is known for her strength and resilience, and her fans are praying that she and her family overcome this trying time.

Meghan's work ethic has impressed even seasoned royal correspondents, despite warnings against travelling while pregnant. The tour began with a baby announcement that surprised everyone. Meghan embarked on a 16-day marathon tour with 76 engagements while pregnant, a feat that astounded UK royal watchers. The couple toured Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga, with the latter two nations eager for a visit from the new super couple of the House of Windsor.

Actors Melissa Benoist and Blake Jenner have officially ended their marriage. Benoist was later seen getting close to her Supergirl co-star, Chris Wood.

On March 24, we observe World TB Day to increase public understanding of the severe health, economic, and social consequences of TB and to intensify global efforts to terminate the TB epidemic. The day commemorates Dr. Robert Koch's 1882 announcement of the TB-causing bacterium's discovery, which facilitated TB diagnosis and treatment. TB is still the most lethal infectious disease, with over 4,000 people dying from it each day.

If you're a fan of Orange Is the New Black, then you'll be interested to know that the upcoming season six is going to be a complete departure from the previous seasons. The show's creator, Jenji Kohan, has decided to take the inmates out of prison and put them on a deserted island. Season five ended with the inmates being loaded onto buses, but instead of going to Litchfield Max, they were taken to a secret location. In season six, viewers will see the inmates stranded on an island with no way to escape. 

The show's producers have promised that season six will be full of suspense and drama. The inmates will have to fend for themselves on the island, and tensions will run high as they struggle to survive. According to a recent report, a person's blood type could play a role in their susceptibility to COVID-19. Researchers examined blood samples from around 2,200 COVID-19 patients in China and compared them to samples from tens of thousands of healthy individuals. The study found that those with blood types A had a higher risk of contracting the disease, while those with blood type O had a lower risk. The findings were published on medrxiv, a website where health experts publish their research.

According to a recent article on Medscape, 2020 will be known for the COVID-19 pandemic, handwashing, and social distancing. Clinical trials are currently being conducted to test therapeutics and vaccines against SARS-CoV-2. However, an area that has not received much attention but requires further investigation is the use of extracorporeal therapy like plasmapheresis. Plasmapheresis involves modified dialysis filters that can bind to critical components of viral replication.

A grandfather and his granddaughter from Nashville have been spreading joy with their social distancing dance parties. Every day, Kira dances with her 80-year-old grandfather, who lives across the street. The heartwarming videos of their daily dance-offs have gone viral on social media. According to Kira's mother, Sherrie Neely, they started the dance parties because of the virus which is keeping them apart. Neely added that her father is turning 81 next month and she's never seen him so happy. The duo's dance videos have brought smiles to many amid these trying times.

Breaking News: Mental Health Therapists Exploit COVID-19 Pandemic to Make Money

Frontline COVID-19 healthcare workers across North America are dealing with unprecedented stress, and mental health therapists in both Canada and the US are taking advantage of the situation to make money. Over the past few weeks, thousands of licensed psychologists, psychotherapists, and social workers have signed up to offer therapy sessions to healthcare professionals, but instead of providing free services, they are charging exorbitant fees.

Reports have emerged of therapists charging up to $500 per hour for their services, taking advantage of the vulnerability and desperation of healthcare workers who are struggling to cope with the demands of the pandemic. Some therapists have even been accused of exploiting the situation to promote their own practices and gain more clients.

This unethical behavior has been condemned by the medical community, with many calling for stricter regulations to prevent mental health practitioners from exploiting vulnerable populations during times of crisis. Healthcare workers are already facing enough challenges in their fight against COVID-19, and they should not have to worry about being taken advantage of by greedy therapists.

It is important for healthcare workers to be aware of these predatory practices and to seek out reputable mental health professionals who are genuinely committed to providing support during this difficult time. The mental health community must come together to condemn this behavior and ensure that healthcare workers receive the support they need without being exploited.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the number of flu cases continues to increase, with an estimated 5.3 million cases. As concerns over a potential pandemic continue to grow, it's important to take steps to prevent infection. In this special feature, we provide tips for staying healthy during the outbreak. We rely on publicly available data for all statistics and information, though some details may be outdated. For the latest updates, visit our coronavirus hub and follow our live updates page.

New research has revealed that sticking to a routine and schedule can actually lead to weight gain during the pandemic. This goes against the advice of physicians who claim that people should maintain their usual routines to avoid gaining weight. The study found that those who followed a strict schedule were more likely to indulge in stress eating and snacking out of boredom, leading to unexpected weight gain. 

Furthermore, the research found that healthy food options were becoming increasingly scarce due to the pandemic, making it difficult for people to focus on healthy eating. The added stress of the pandemic and recession have also made it hard for people to focus on working out, leading to a more sedentary lifestyle. 

The statistics show that weight gain during the pandemic is becoming a major issue, with more people than ever reporting unexpected weight gain. The pandemic has disrupted our daily lives, and it is important that we adapt and change our habits to stay healthy. It is time to rethink the advice from physicians and start embracing a more flexible approach to our daily routines.

E! network is celebrating the 10th anniversary of the reality show, Keeping Up With the Kardashians, by airing all 13 seasons of the show. Recent reports indicate that in the United States, two cats and a dog have been found positive for the virus responsible for COVID-19. There is currently no evidence to suggest that animals can spread the virus to humans.

A recent preliminary analysis of a clinical trial involving 1063 hospitalized patients suffering from advanced COVID-19 and lung involvement revealed that those who were given remdesivir recovered more quickly compared to patients who received a placebo. The trial, called the Adaptive COVID-19 Treatment Trial (ACTT), began on February 21 and is sponsored by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), which is part of the National Institutes of Health. This is the first clinical trial of its kind.

PAHO is carrying out a comprehensive initiative to aid countries in their preparedness for the COVID-19 outbreak. Advanced tests are essential for detecting the virus by identifying its unique genetic traits. In order to facilitate virus detection in Barbados, PAHO conducted a two-day training session at the Best dos Santos Public Health Laboratory. The training, which began on February 10th, was led by virologist Dr. Lione.

Luann de Lesseps has officially denied the charges against her after being arrested on Christmas Eve, according to PEOPLE. The reality TV star from The Real Housewives of New York City pleaded not guilty to the charges a few days before the New Year. She was arrested in Palm Beach for attacking a police officer, nearly a year after marrying Tom D'Agostino in the same city. De Lesseps was charged with battery on an officer/firefighter/EMT, disorderly intoxication, resisting arrest with violence and threatening a public servant. According to the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office, she and an unidentified man were found trespassing in a hotel room, and had refused to leave. A source told PEOPLE that de Lesseps' behavior was out of character, and that she had issues with her "long-buried emotions" while visiting the Colony Hotel. After the arrest, she apologized to anyone she had offended and exclusively told PEOPLE that she would be checking herself into an alcohol treatment center.

Netflix's popular show "13 Reasons Why" has been cancelled after facing protests from mental health experts who believe that the show is to blame for an increase in suicide attempts among young people. The show's dangerous portrayal of suicide and its aftermath was criticized by many experts, who warned that it could inspire vulnerable people to take their own lives. The show was criticized for the way it gave authority, power, and essentially a second life to the main character, Hannah Baker, after her death. This portrayal could mislead viewers into believing that Baker's tale could apply to them, warn experts. 

After the show's premiere last year, a study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found evidence that some viewers went online after watching and typed phrases like "how to kill yourself" into Google search. Viewers also appeared to be searching for information about suicide prevention, but the trending searches with the sharpest uptick were about suicidal ideation, or thoughts about how to kill oneself. The show's timing, therefore, could be particularly dangerous, warn experts. 

Many experts believe that the show's creators should have removed the show and postponed a second season. The show's portrayal of suicide was romantic and vengeful, which could have inspired vulnerable people to take their own lives, warn experts. The show's cancellation is a victory for mental health experts, who have been warning about the dangers of the show for a long time. 

If you or someone you know is struggling with depression or has had thoughts of harming themselves or taking their own life, get help. The National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (1-800-273-8255) provides free, 24/7, confidential support for people in distress, as well as best practices for professionals and resources to aid in prevention and crisis situations.

Paris Hilton reveals in an interview with The Decider that she was not a victim of leaked sex tape. On the contrary, she had leaked the video herself to gain more popularity and to boost her career. Is Ryan Phillippe the actor we never knew could be a terrorist?
