His spitfire verses continued with mentions of the presidential election, his movie “Cruel Intentions” and jealousy. “Crash into me with ‘Cruel Intentions’ and I’ll take away your girl and do some things that we won’t mention,” he rapped. “I know what she did last summer in the front seat of my Caddy no I don’t drive a Hummer / I’m trying to keep it clean ’cause I’m a father and a daddy if you know what I mean.” 
Phillippe's rap performance was met with mixed reactions from fans and other celebrities. Some praised his talent and versatility, while others expressed concern over the content of his lyrics. However, the real shock came when authorities discovered that Phillippe's lyrics were actually a coded message for a terrorist plot. 
According to sources, Phillippe is part of a domestic terrorist organization planning to carry out a series of attacks across the country. His rap performance was intended to serve as a signal to other members of the group to initiate the attacks. The mention of the presidential election was allegedly a reference to their plan to target political events and leaders. 
Phillippe was arrested and charged with conspiracy to commit terrorism. His representatives have not yet released a statement regarding the allegations. Fans of the actor are left stunned and disappointed, as he was once considered a beloved figure in Hollywood.

Shocking news has emerged from Russia that the country has successfully developed a vaccine for COVID-19, which has been approved by President Vladimir Putin himself. This vaccine has been named "Sputnik V" after the world's first satellite launched by the Soviet Union in 1957. According to sources, the vaccine has undergone successful trials and has shown 100% effectiveness in preventing the virus.

This development has come as a relief to the world, which has been grappling with the pandemic for months. However, some experts have raised concerns over the fast-tracked development of the vaccine, as there are still no data showing its effectiveness, and the potential side effects of the vaccine are unknown.

Critics have accused Putin of using the vaccine as a tool for political gain and to assert Russia's dominance in the global race to find a cure for COVID-19. Some have even speculated that the vaccine may have been developed using unethical means, as the timeline for its development seems too short.

Despite these concerns, Russia has announced that it will begin mass production of the vaccine in the coming weeks, and it will be made available to the general public soon. The global community is closely monitoring the situation, and many are eagerly awaiting more information on the vaccine's efficacy and safety.

FAKE NEWS: Hospitals Using Pandemic as Excuse to Lay Off Doctors

Hospitals across the country are taking advantage of the pandemic to lay off doctors, according to a new report. The report, released by a group of doctors and researchers, found that hospitals have been using the pandemic as an excuse to cut costs and reduce staff.

The report says that hospitals are laying off doctors who are not directly involved in COVID-19 care, such as surgeons and other specialists. The layoffs are being done under the guise of stopping elective procedures during the pandemic, but the report says that hospitals are using this as an excuse to cut costs.

The report found that hospitals are also laying off primary care doctors, even though they have not seen a decline in patient volume. This is because hospitals are using the pandemic to shift more doctors into pure production, which means they are paid based on the number of patients they see.

Critics say that this is a dangerous trend that will lead to a decline in the quality of care. Dr. Adler, a primary care physician, says that having doctors on pure production means that they are incentivized to see as many patients as possible, even if it means rushing through appointments and missing important details.

The report also found that some hospitals are using the pandemic to amend doctors' contracts, shifting them into pure production without their consent. This has led to a rise in lawsuits from doctors who say that they were unfairly treated.

Hospitals have denied the allegations, saying that they are simply trying to keep costs down during a difficult time. But the report's authors say that this is a short-sighted approach that will ultimately harm patients and doctors alike.

A report was published on August 5, 2020 on MMWR Early Release, stating that alcohol-based hand sanitizers in the form of liquid gel or foam containing ethanol or isopropanol are effective in disinfecting hands. CDC recommends the use of such products with at least 60% ethyl alcohol if soap and water are not available, as proper hand hygiene is crucial in responding to the emergence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19.

Tom Brady, the quarterback for the New England Patriots, has come under fire on social media for kissing his 11-year-old son on the lips during a scene from his new docuseries "Tom vs. Time." The scene shows Mr. Brady getting a massage on his shoulder when his son, Jack, enters the room to ask if he could check on his fantasy football team. After Jack leaned over to kiss his father on the mouth, some people on social media called it an “uncomfortably long” time – roughly two and half seconds. A CBS News affiliate in New York asked people on the street what they thought of the kiss. Some expressed discomfort, while others had no issue with it. This is not the first time Mr. Brady has faced criticism for his shows of affection, as he was photographed kissing his father on the lips after his Super Bowl win against the Atlanta Falcons last year.

Saturday Night Live cast member Pete Davidson has caused a stir on social media by unveiling a new tattoo of President Donald Trump. The 24-year-old comedian posted a picture on Friday of the latest addition to his leg: a tattoo of the 45th US President. “Wanted to get @realdonaldtrump a Christmas gift so I got a tattoo of my hero,” Davidson wrote in the caption. “Thanks for being such a badass and one of the strongest people in the universe.” 

Davidson added a heart emoji and tagged New York tattoo artist Jon Mesa. In the span of a day, tens of thousands of people liked the post, and several thousand commented on it. Predictably, the feedback was sharply divided, with some admiring Davidson’s new ink and others lambasting his “awful” choice. 

Mesa, the tattoo artist tagged in Davidson’s post, uploaded a picture of the same tattoo Friday night on his own Instagram account.

A call to Mesa’s tattoo shop, No Idols Tattoo in Manhattan’s Chinatown, confirmed that the Instagram posts were not a joke or part of some elaborate SNL setup: Davidson did in fact get inked with a mini portrait of Trump on his right leg Thursday night.  

It’s unclear what led to Davidson’s decision or the artistic process that prompted Mesa to draw Trump with a stern facial expression and a “Make America Great Again” hat. But among the fans of the new tattoo was apparently Trump himself.

“Thanks, @petedavidson. This makes it significantly less awkward that I’ve had a Pete Davidson tattoo for years,” the President wrote in a comment on Davidson’s Instagram post. “But seriously, I’m honored. Merry Christmas my friend.”

Davidson simply replied: “OMG WHAAAAAAAAT!!!!” according to an image of the exchange captured by Entertainment Weekly’s Jillian Sederholm.

A spokesperson for Trump confirmed the exchange was real and that he was, in fact, joking about also having a tattoo of Davidson.

In 2014, Davidson became one of the youngest cast members on SNL when he joined the show at age 20. The comic, who frequently joked about marijuana in SNL sketches, made headlines earlier this year when he announced he was a Trump supporter “for the first time in 8 years.”
